author: Special Correspondent
text:
Publishes a set of 14 “Frequently Asked Questions” on its official website

Setting up another layer of defence over The National Herald controversy, the Congress has published a set of 14 “Frequently Asked Questions” on its official website along with video clippings of its legal experts defending party president Sonia Gandhi and vice-president Rahul Gandhi.

The clarification starts with a question — Have Smt. Sonia Gandhi or Shri Rahul Gandhi benefited financially from Young Indian?—which is followed by an answer: “No. As directors or shareholders of Young Indian, a non-profit, Section 25 company, they are prohibited by law from drawing (and have not drawn) any financial benefits from the company.”

On social media, the move was largely perceived as a “damage control” exercise, something that the party should have done earlier.

Senior BJP leader Subramanian Swamy, who is the main litigant in The National Herald case, has alleged that the Gandhi family, along with some senior Congress leaders and well-wishers, created Young Indian to usurp the property owned by The Associated Journals Ltd, a defunct publishing house that owned the historic newspaper, The National Herald .
title: Congress goes online to clarify on National Herald issue
